These texts are beneficial to both novice researchers and seasoned academics, offering new perspectives and information on a variety of topics.

Military biography

Your summary of military experience is meant to highlight the most important aspects of your training and experience, and it is the board's primary way of 'meeting' you.

Autobiography

When we read books, we often experience the story through the eyes of the main character. But what would it be like to have your own story as a book? A memoir or autobiography is a personal book that shares a person's life experiences and details. There are many ways to approach writing an auto-biography but with so many different ways to do it, how do you choose which one is right for you? If you are interested in writing your auto-biography, keep reading for some useful tips and tricks on how to get started.

If you're currently serving as a member of the armed forces or you've recently finished your service, writing an autobiography about your military experiences can be a rewarding way to document that part of your past. Keeping track of all these stories and details can be difficult after so much time has passed, but writing them all down will help you remember those experiences later on in life.

Types of headlamps

Headlamps come in many different shapes and sizes, but there are a few things you need to know before you make your final purchase. We'll break down the options below so you can make an educated decision.

Incandescent headlamps

The most common type of headlamp is the incandescent bulb. These are cheap, compact, and easy to use. They're also great for camping or emergency preparedness kits because they don't require batteries. The downside is that they're inefficient, which means you'll have to spend more money on electricity to run them. Also, they're not very durable, so you'll have to replace them often.

LED headlamps

These are the most popular headlamps today. They're efficient, long-lasting, and durable. They're also affordable, making them a great option for beginners. The downside is that they're expensive. You'll have to pay at least $100 for one of these. That's why we recommend getting started with incandescent headlamps first. Once you get comfortable with that, you can move up to LED headlamps. If you want to save some money, check out our list of the best budget LED headlamps.

Fluorescent headlamps

These are another option worth considering. They're inexpensive, compact, and easy to use. However, they're not as efficient as LED headlamps, so you'll have to spend more money on electricity to run them. Also, they're not durable, so you'll have to replace them often. Still, they're worth checking out if you want to stick to a budget.

Solar headlamps

This is powered by the sun. They can be stationary or portable light fixtures with rechargeable batteries, photovoltaic solar panels, controllers, and LED lamps. They do not require any wiring because they are powered by solar radiation.

Types of rifle cases

When purchasing a rifle case, keep in mind the key features and what you need the case to do. Shoulder straps, hard or soft, long-term storage, TSA compatibility, and additional storage space are all important considerations.

Hard case

These are your classic tough, box-style, hard-sided cases. Usually made from injected-molded plastics and clip shut, they can run the widest range in quality. Many rifles will come in their own cheaply manufactured hard cases, with flimsy clips that barely latch and hinges that are prone to break, but on the other end of the spectrum, you see enormously well-constructed bunkers with pressure relief valves, dual wall construction, and laser-cut foam cutouts on the inside. Pelican famously used to drop its rifle cases out of a helicopter to demonstrate the ruggedness of construction, and there are now several competitors in that range of high-quality construction.

Soft case

Soft rifle cases are your classic soft, handbag-style carry cases, usually complete with padded interiors to protect the rifle from impact. They're lighter, easier to carry around, pack in a trunk and work with in general, at the cost of less protection. These can often overlap with drag bags, especially when enough extra storage pouches are slapped on. You'll also see backpack-style soft cases, usually for hunters who need to travel long distances into the woods with all their gear, in addition to a scoped rifle they want to protect from the elements.

Drag bag

Drag bags started as a military rifle carry option where it was necessary to have a durable soft case bag that carried all the assorted accouterment associated with the weapon stored inside. Called so because of their ability to be dragged behind a crawling sniper in the field, they have evolved into a reliable rifle case option in their own right. The hallmarks of a drag bag are extensive storage and high-quality protective construction. Think of it as a go-bag for the gun inside, bearing all the magazines, accessories, and maintenance gear the weapon needs to function in the field, and you've got the right idea. Many drag bags even still bear a loop at the top, used for the dragging that gave this class its name.

Types of camping generators

Camping can take many different forms, so it stands to reason that the best camping generators will come in a variety of shapes and sizes as well. After you've calculated your electrical requirements through a thorough gear audit, you'll need to consider how you'll generate and store that amount of power.

Fuel-burning generators

There are a few reasons fuel-burning generators have stood the test of time. First, combustible fuel is relatively cheap and abundant. For just a few dollars, you can run a gas-powered generator for hours. Refilling your generator tank takes a few seconds, and modern internal combustion engines are extremely reliable.

On the other hand, there's something about venturing into the quiet wilderness and firing up a noisy, exhaust-belching generator that doesn't sit well with a lot of people. Fuel-burning generators also require you to carry all the fuel you'll need, which can get heavy and potentially messy. If you need a whole lot of power with little to no downtime, the pros outweigh the cons. Otherwise, the next category might be what you need.

Solar generators

Solar generators are experiencing rapid growth in popularity, partially as a result of technological improvements that are making them more efficient and easier to carry than ever before. Unlike fuel-burning generators, solar-powered energy banks are very quiet or completely silent, produce no emissions, and can draw power directly from the sun. Theyre is just as popular with environmentally conscious campers and off-grid preppers.

The biggest drawback of solar generators is the amount of time it takes to recharge the battery. Instead of spending a few seconds pouring fuel into a tank, you'll need several hours of intense sunlight and large, expensive solar panels. If you have plenty of sun and time to wait, a solar generator is probably your best bet for camping.

Power banks

Full-size generators are great for camping trips that involve an Overlanding vehicle, RV, or boat, but they're way too big and heavy for backpacking or carrying into the field for personal use. If you weigh your gear in ounces, a power bank is all you can afford to carry.

Types of tactical knives

Tactical knives come in a variety of shapes and sizes. Whatever task you have in mind or what your local restrictions are, you're likely to find a tactical knife that meets your requirements. There are types of tactical knives that fill a specific role.

Fixed blade

Any knife with a blade that is "fixed" in place and one that is securely affixed to the handle and lacks a pivot is considered a fixed blade. In many ways, they're the polar opposite of pocket knives. Unless sheathed, the blade is always visible. Due to the lack of a complicated locking mechanism, they are straightforward, easier to manufacture than folding knives, and very user-friendly. The more resilient fixed blades are designed with a full tang, where the portion of the blade inside the handle has the same shape as the handle. Unfortunately, most inexpensive fixed blades are not; they contain a weak metal "tail" that is frequently epoxied or pinned inside the handle and are more prone to breaking.

Folding

Also known as pocket knives, folders are compact knives that contain at least one blade that folds into the handle, preventing the need for a bulky sheath. Conveniently carried in your pocket, they're legal in most municipalities and can be extremely handy for everyday tasks. Some are quite, but the majority will have blades between three to four inches in length. Folders are extremely versatile, despite being typically smaller and weaker than their fixed blade brethren.

Types of ultralight sleeping bags

Based on their design, ultralight sleeping bags are classified as Mummy Bags or Quilts. However, there are numerous variations and hybrids of these two simple designs.

Mummy Bags

Mummy bags are the most common style of the three-season sleeping bag. They are designed to enclose you completely like a mummy and are shaped just like the Pharaohs you can see at the museum. They are narrow at the feet and legs and wider through the torso. Most mummy bags have a large hood that fully covers your head and can be cinched tight around your face to allow only the tiniest opening to breathe through, thereby giving you the very best protection against the cold. Mummy bags help you stay warm by only leaving a small amount of space inside the bag that is unfilled by your body, meaning less air to heat. This also makes them feel constricted and claustrophobic. Compared to quilts, these bags tend to be the easiest to use, as the design is familiar to most and less complicated.

Backpacking Quilts

Down quilts are a versatile solution to the feeling of constriction that is inherent in a mummy bag design. They also manage to save weight by not including as much material or insulation and also nixing the hood and zipper. The basic premise is that to be an effective insulator, down needs to be able to loft up and create space that traps air. When you are sleeping on top of the down, it is fully compressed, thereby losing the vast majority of its insulating abilities.

Types of paracord bracelets

When most people hear the word "paracord," they immediately think of the seven-strand, 550-pound rated version from which most of these bracelets are made. Other sizes and materials fall under the paracord label as well. Let's take a look to make sure you have the best survival cord available.

Mil-spec

To start with, there is a paracord made to military spacifications and paracord that isnt. One of the key requirements is that the cord is made from nylon. For the 550-rated paracord, there must be seven to nine core strands as well. Unless your cord is marked, it can be difficult to identify paracord as mil-spec.

Nylon

Having been around for many decades, nylon is commonly found in clothing and various other products. It is a plastic-based fiber that is stronger than other naturally occurring fibers. Nylon will melt when exposed to a flame.

Polyester

Another synthetic fiber, polyester, is often cheaper than nylon. This is the material of choice for lesser-quality paracords as its moreit'sfordable. The downside is that it isnt as strong as nylon, which is why polyester paracord doesnt cut the mil-spec mustard.

Types of field jackets

Field jackets come in all shapes and sizes, so it's important to know what you're getting into before you make a purchase.

M-65

This is the classic military jacket. These jackets all share the hallmarks of the original design: the stowable hood, large pockets, and a detachable liner for extra warmth in cold conditions. They're usually a cotton/poly blend for better water resistance and durability, and many are treated for additional waterproofing.

The nice thing about an M-65 is the tried-and-true design. It's been field-tested to death, so you know it's going to work when you most need it without fail. Another benefit? The internal liner is just a woobie shaped like a coat, and it's impossible to be unhappy about that. Everybody loves their woobie.

Hunting jackets

Hunting field jackets tend to deviate a bit from the classic M-65 design philosophy, with synthetic materials or oilskin being more prevalent and hoods being less common, but they keep a lot of the features we love. Lots of large pockets, superb warmth, and excellent weather resistance are all hallmarks.

Another difference is the fit where the classic design is deliberately oversized and baggy, hunting jackets tend to be a little more form-fitting and snug. This helps avoid snagging on branches and underbrush as you move through the woods, but a good hunting jacket achieves this without sacrificing freedom of movement.

Workwear

Many workwear companies have their own field jacket style designs, but they can be a stark departure from the original design. As with hunting jackets, hoods are less common, and they often lack the abundant storage space as other options.

Types of molle pouches

MOLLE is an acronym that stands for "MOdular Light Load-carrying Equipment." It is also known as PALS, which stands for "Pouch Attachment Ladder System." MOLLE works by stitching rows of nylon straps down in 40mm increments to form a series of loops. You weave straps found on the back of MOLLE-compatible pouches through these loops, which secures the pouch to whatever mounting surface it is attached to.

Magazine pouches come in a variety of sizes and shapes. , In general, there are four major types of magazine pouches: cloth, thermoplastic, hybrid, and leather. Take a look at the different types and what they're typically used for.

Cloth

These are the simplest, and often most cost-effective types of pouches on the market. At their core, they're a cloth bag, usually made of nylon Cordura, with some sort of closure on top, be it a velcro flap, a snap flap, a bungee, or some other mechanism. These pouches are also the most common on the surplus market, having been around since the advent of MOLLE, and so they can be had for very cheap if you're on a budget. The advantages that they have is that they usually work well with at least one of most magazines and that they're fairly easy to use for re-indexing. The disadvantage is that generally their flap closures can get in the way during reloads, and they have no form of inherent retention beyond the flap.

Thermoplastic

These pouches (or carriers as I prefer to call them since they aren't a bag) are made of flexible thermoplastic, which is a substance that includes the Kydex family of materials. This allows manufacturers to mold magazine carriers to specific magazines, firearms, and other implements, and have them securely held with no need for other retention in most cases. The advantage to this type of carrier is that they offer positive retention with no need for bungees, straps, or flaps, and instead rely on friction from the molded plastic to hold the magazine in place, which makes them some of the fastest on the list. The downside to these is that they're often only compatible with one or two types of magazine, and aren't flexible in allowing non-standard types of magazines, should you be a weirdo who uses G36 magazines or AUG magazines.

Hybrid

These pouches use a combination of cloth and other materials to provide their retention, whether through the use of gripping material, elastic tension, thermoplastic inserts, or some other type of solution. These pouches seek to offer a best of both worlds approach and often include both thermoplastic liners and some other form of optional retention. The advantage to these pouches is that they solve the biggest issue with many of the pure cloth or purely thermoplastic options, providing a mixture of retention and flexibility. The disadvantage is large that they inherit some of the issues of both cloth and plastic magazine carriers and the fact that they're oftentimes still very pricey.

Leather

This isn't an option that I discussed on this list, largely for the reason that we were speaking about rifle magazines and the fact that I wanted every pouch on this list to have some sort of military usage. Leather is possibly the oldest ammo-carrying solution, oftentimes offering intricately embossed designs, brass hardware, and other stylish choices. The advantages of leather largely boil down to style and comfort. Not much looks nicer than well-tanned and finished leather and it's very comfortable to wear on your belt in a concealment environment. Additionally, this may be the only option for pouches if you're in a law enforcement environment, due to departmental restrictions or a desire for uniformity. The disadvantage of leather is that it doesn't play well with moisture, doesn't offer the cost-effectiveness of cloth or the rock-solid retention of thermoplastic, and has limited options for securing the pouch.

Types of camping mugs

Camping mugs come in a variety of different sizes, shapes, and materials. Each has its place in the world of backpacking, car camping, or hiking. The following are some examples of camping mugs you can find on the market today.

Tumbler

Tumbler-style coffee cups are the most popular and versatile. They tend to be tall and tapered toward the bottom, shaped similarly to the water glass.

The lack of a handle makes them fit easily into cup holders. While usually not completely spill-proof, their lids prevent total spills and help retain heat and cold.

Thermos/Flask

These tend to be completely spill-proof and prioritize insulation over ease of drinking. They are best for people who want to keep their drink hot or cold all day long.

Mug

Certain camping mugs are closer in design to the classic ceramic mug. They are shorter and broader with a built-in handle. The handle makes them more comfortable to hold, but it also prevents them from fitting in most cup holders, limiting their use.

Brand-specific

Some camping mugs come included with mess kits or camping cookware sets. They usually fit snugly into the sets of other containers or cookware, making packing them a cinch. However, they aren't that good at insulating and are sometimes awkward to drink out of.

Types of machetes

Machetes come in a variety of styles and sizes. The machete has evolved many styles, features, and adaptations for specific uses and environments throughout its long history in many rural areas around the world. Names and styles vary by region and frequently overlap, so the same machete may be referred to by different names in different areas. Preferences for one style over another are generally subjective, and, as with many other things, are heavily influenced by region, tradition, and experience. When choosing a machete, the most important consideration is what feels right to you.

Barong Machetes

Barong machetes are known for their unique leaf-shaped blade, which is traditionally only sharpened on one side. The traditional cutting tool of certain tribes in the Philippines, the barong was feared by European colonizers for its ability to cut through rifle barrels.

Billhook Machetes

The billhook machete is an ancient agricultural cutting tool with a curved blade meant for chopping around objects, such as tree trunks, and for " snedding", which is the process of stripping side shoots and buds from a branch. The hooked blade, sharpened on the inner curve, is ideally suited for gripping and cutting vines and brambles.

Bolo Machetes

The bolo machete is popular in Southeastern Asia where it is commonly used as a farming and agricultural tool. The bolo machete excels as a harvesting tool for narrow row crops, such as rice, soybeans, peanuts, and mung beans due to the distinctive bulge, adding heft to the fore blade that provides additional chopping power.

Bowie Machetes

The Bowie machete features a clip-point or skinner tip for skinning wild game. This style is named after American frontiersman Jim Bowie and is popular amongst survivalists and backwoodsmen.

Bush Machetes

A popular all-purpose machete with a normal, straight back blade. The blade tends to be evenly weighted and fairly stout. Very portable, and can be fitted with a sheath easily for carrying around.

Cane Machetes

Wide, blunt-tipped machetes perfect for hacking corn stalks and sugar cane. Often the blade is hooked to allow the user to pull the chopped cane from the plants still standing. The thin blade thickness allows for easy cutting through cane-style vegetation.

Colima Machetes

Sharpened on both sides of the blade to allow for a sweeping cut motion on both the fore and backhand strokes. Colima machetes are typically weighted on the back side for aid in clearing the backstroke.

Hawkbill Machetes

A curved or hooked machete that can be sharpened on both sides or the inside of the curve. The sharpened tip concentrates force on a sharp point allowing it to pierce and cut very hard materials, while the inner curve facilitates the reaping and collecting of stalked vegetation.

Kukri

Kukri have 3 parts to their blade, a pointed tip for stabbing, a wide midsection for chopping, and a narrow area near the handle for whittling and carving.

Pang Machetes

Machete design popular in Africa and the Caribbean. A deep belly provides weight for chopping and curvature for slicing. The upturned point can concentrate force on a small area for piercing.

Parang Machetes

Parang machetes, also known as Golok machetes, generally have a distinctive curved shape in which both the spine and the edge of the blade are curved, much like a scimitar. They tend to be long and either slightly weighted or fairly evenly weighted, and usually have a thick blade.

Weighted/Heavy Machetes

The workhorse of the machetes. The terms "weighted" or "heavy" refers to how the weight is distributed in the blade design. The heavy or weighted machete has the bulk of the weight towards the top of the blade to make chopping thick and woody vegetation easier.

Types of backpacking backpacks

External frame, internal frame, and frameless backpacks are the three types of backpacking packs. In terms of size, they are measured in liters and are commonly referred to as daypacks, weekend backpacks, multi-day backpacks, and extended trip/expedition packs.

The various frame styles can be perplexing, especially if you have no prior experience backpacking or rucking. Look for the backpacks for backpacking listed below.

Frameless backpacks

This type is very light with flexible construction and is designed to carry light loads. A frameless backpacking pack lacks any rods or frame sheets to distribute weight. They generally do hold more than 40 liters and are not meant to carry a heavy load.

Internal frame backpacks

This type is the most popular type of backpacking pack available, and features a more rigid construction that distributes weight more, and keeps the backpacking pack from collapsing. They're often made with a frame sheet on the inside.

External frame packs

This type features a frame often made of aluminum on the outside, with a harness attached to it. They're used for carrying very heavy loads. They are not as commonly available in modern times, but some companies still offer this style due to their highly adjustable style, and customizable nature.

Types of gun safes

There are several high-quality gun safes under $500 on the market right now. The most difficult challenge will be selecting a safe that is both secure and reliable. With so many unknown manufacturers producing products in this market, you must exercise caution.

Choose the best gun safe for less than $500.

Long gun safes

These are what we traditionally see and think of when we think of gun safes - a big, tall, sturdy safe with a large door that swings open to reveal rifles and shotguns lined up along the interior walls with some shelves for handguns and ammo. These safes tend to be bulky and hard to move but offer great protection from theft and fire because they can be secured to the ground with bolts and have plenty of insulation protecting your investments from fire damage.

Handgun safes

Handgun safes tend to be much smaller and have limited space. Most can be bolted down to the ground to prevent someone from simply picking them up and walking away. Quality handgun safes have insulation to protect against fire damage and flooding, while cheaper options will only offer the bare minimum level of protection against theft or child access. Some handgun lock boxes can be mounted to a bed frame and be opened quickly with the firearm being in an easy-to-access position allowing for a full firing grip from the get-go.

Lockboxes and locking cabinets

These options can be used when security is not a major concern as they offer the lowest level of security. A few minutes with a simple crowbar and any thief with some upper body strength will be walking away with some shiny new guns. If a lock box or cabinet is going to be your choice, it would be wise to layer your home security with things such as heavy doors, alarm systems, big scary dogs, etc., because these safes are not going to slow someone down on their own.

Hidden safes

Hidden safes come in different forms, but most of the time they require the user to cut a hole in the wall of their home and secure the safe to the studs. Up until recently, these safes followed more traditional designs and would require that the user place something over the front to conceal the door. Today, there are more options with everything from shelves to mirrors that are both "safe" as well as concealment furniture. Safes that are hidden in plain sight can help mitigate the risk of a burglar finding where you keep your guns if they are just inside for a short amount of time in a smash-and-grab type of robbery. Most thieves will know to look in the common areas for unsecured firearms such as under the mattress, inside a closet, or in a dresser, so having a more incognito place to put your guns could work better in some cases.

Types of canvas backpacks

Canvas backpacks are well-known for their durability, as they are made of high-quality, 100% waxed canvas materials. Canvas backpacks are available in a variety of styles and designs.

Vintage canvas

Vintage backpack brings you timeless ergonomics combined with rugged, weather-proof materials that not only stand the test of time but also evolve to fit every shape and size of your style with its resilient and functional, yet simplistic classic style.

Waxed canvas

The durable good looks and ample space of the waxed canvas backpack make it a practical hiking companion. Take your upcoming hike in style with a handcrafted, eco-friendly backpack that includes everything you will need.

Canvass drawstring

This canvas drawstring backpack combines the best of the old and new, urban and rural, into one sleek design. Whether you're discovering new modern cities or ancient forests, this canvas drawstring backpack will keep everything close at hand.

Canvas laptop

With the canvas laptop backpack, you can travel into the unknown and experience the thrill of primitive explorers as they discovered the land of the full moon. Conquer stunning landscapes in culture's outskirts and let your spirit skyrocket.

Types of go bags

There are a lot of options out there for go bags. It can be overwhelming to pick the right one, so we've narrowed it down to four categories based on what you need it for.

Get-home bags

Get-home bags are designed to be light and comfortable. You should be able to run at least a mile without difficulty. The bag you choose should also be small enough to be stored out of sight in your car so it's always there when you need it without drawing unwanted attention. Choose a color that's subdued and makes sense for your environment - camouflage isn't a great option for urban environments, but shades of brown and green are pretty versatile.

Three-day bags

The consensus for midsized go bags is that they should be able to sustain a person for three days. That covers food, water, first aid kit, ammunition, clothing, and anything else you might need. These bags tend to be in the 30- to 50-liter size range and should have some way to add gear with MOLLE panels. While you probably wouldn't want to run more than a few hundred yards wearing a three-day bag, you should still be able to cover ground at a good clip with short bursts of running and climbing when necessary.

Long-term go bags

In a worst-case scenario, you may not be able to return home. Circumstances may force you to keep moving for weeks on end or cover great distances on foot. In that case, your pack will look more like something an Appalachian Trail through-hiker would use than what you'd see during a week-long field exercise. Simply put, your pack should be able to sustain you indefinitely.

That means that instead of food and water, you'll need to bring equipment for acquiring food and water. Maybe a sleeping bag and small tent are worth some extra weight.

Types of 4-season tents

There are a lot of options when it comes to buying a tent. The good news is that most tents can be used for more than one season, so you can get the right fit without breaking the bank.

Mountaineering

Mountaineering tents are built for high-alpine environments with weight as a primary consideration. Many of these tents are of the single-wall variety and make few compromises in terms of wind and weather protection. Square footage tends to be lower than base camping and treeline tents, and the same goes for peak height. Almost all mountaineering tents are waterproof, or easily seam-sealed, with one exception, being the lightweight

Basecamp

4-season tents of the base camping variety are more comfortable and heavier than their mountaineering siblings above. You may not have to carry your tent as far or as high, and therefore you can get away with packing more weight (and getting more tent in return). In addition, you'll likely end up spending more time in a basecamp-style tent. Mountaineering tents are designed for fast and light adventures and summit pushes, but base camping can be done in a variety of circumstances and conditions. Many of these tents have a double-wall design, which helps with ventilation, condensation prevention, and space, all at the expense of weight.

Treeline

Treeline tents are the most trimmed-down 4-season models on the market. As the name implies, they are designed for winter camping but not necessarily for heavy exposure in the high mountains. Compared to a 3-season version, a treeline tent will have a more substantial bathtub floor, less mesh, and heavier canopy and rainfly fabrics. But these tents fall short of basecamp and mountaineering models in terms of their toughness and durability, and it's best not to put them to the test. They are, however, a nice option for light winter adventuring and serious 3-season backpacking in unpredictable weather.

Types of gun cases

Since gun cases are sized to fit specific firearm types, such as handguns or long guns, they are organized based on the materials used to create the case, the quantity of guns it can hold, and whether or not the case looks like a gun case.

Gun cases come in many different sizes and configurations. The most common types are pistol cases, rifle cases, shotgun cases, and handgun cases. Each category has the unique features that make it a good choice for certain shooters.

Hard shell case

A hard gun case offers the most protection out of all the types of gun cases. They're constructed from either metal or a durable polymer shell, and the interior is lined with foam padding. Together, they protect the contents from environmental threats and impact. Compared to a soft case, a hard case is bulkier, but it's a must if you plan on traveling with a firearm.

Soft shell case

A soft shell gun case is meant for quick access and flexibility, such as range or hunting trips. They're made out of materials like nylon, polyester, and leather with some padding. Additionally, soft cases offer a range of storage options. You can find simple designs that just carry a gun and others with multiple pockets for magazines and other gear.

Multi-gun case

A multi-gun case is not limited to being a hard or soft shell, but rather a design that's large enough to carry multiple firearms.

Discreet gun case

Gun cases that don't look like gun cases are growing in popularity. More often than not, they're referred to as discreet gun cases. Sometimes they're shaped like a guitar case, violin case, tennis bag, or just a backpack.

Types of aviator sunglasses

There are various styles and materials that today's aviators are made from, as well as which lenses will give you the best overhead sun protection and color saturation so that you can see better and look great whether you're flying the wild blue yonder or just out and about. Here are the styles to consider.

Classic Teardrop

It's the classic aviator look. If you're buying an aviator because you want to tap into its rich, high-octane heritage, then go with it. On a functional basis, the teardrop shape provides the most coverage from sunlight.

Navigator

The Navigator aviator sunglasses are a classic style with a modern twist. The lenses are a gradient brown, which gets darker at the top to block out the sun. The frames are made of lightweight metal, and the arms have a slight curve to them for a comfortable fit. It's more squared off than the teardrop shape and will set you apart from the rest of the aviator-wearing crowd and is an ideal shape for men with longer faces. If you're looking for a new take on a timeless style, the Navigator aviator sunglasses are the perfect choice.

Sporty

If you have an active lifestyle and you want to sport some aviator shades while biking or running, check out the more sporty-shaped lenses some companies are putting out. Sporty aviators have a squared-off bottom, but the lenses themselves are wider, which allows them to wrap around your face to help keep more sun out. Because they're squared off at the bottom, sporty aviators aren't going to be as front-heavy as traditional teardrop aviators.

Types of water purification tablets

For purification, three types of chemicals are used. They are based on iodine, chlorine, or chlorine dioxide. Each uses a unique chemical process to purify water, with varying degrees of success for each type of microorganism. To best suit your purification strategy, become acquainted with the various types of purification chemicals.

Iodine-Based (Tetraglycine Hydroperiodide)

Iodine, which comes as a solution, crystal, or tablet is a chemical compound commonly used for water purification and is especially effective in the eradication of microorganisms such as bacteria, viruses, and parasites. For water to be completely purified, it needs to sit for at least 30 minutes after the chemical has been added.

The temperature of the water to be purified has a very important effect on the effectiveness of iodine as a purifier. Generally, it takes a longer time to purify cooler water than it does to purify warmer water. Also, the quality of the water also influences the amount of iodine needed. Cloudy water generally requires more iodine than clear water. If the water contains visible particles, be sure to strain the water before adding iodine.

Chlorine-Based Tablets (Sodium dichloroisocyanurate)

The process of using chlorine as a means of purification it is referred to as chlorination. Discovered over a century ago, chlorine is especially effective in eliminating bacteria and viruses that cause diseases such as dysentery, typhoid, gastroenteritis, and cholera.

Chlorine disinfects water by first destroying the cell membrane of microorganisms which allows it to then enter and disrupt the cell s respiration and DNA activity. By combining it with effervescent salts such as sodium bicarbonate and adipic acid, these rapidly dissolving tablets become highly effective at eliminating a wide range of bacteria and viruses. Chlorine is considered to be ineffective against eliminating Cryptosporidium due to its protective shell and partially effective against Giardia.

Chlorine-based tablets are generally considered to be superior to its liquid form due to the additional effervescent salts which increase effectiveness and also because the liquid version tends to degrade with age. To use chlorine as a purifier, simply add the chlorine-based tablets to the appropriate amount of water and allow to stand in a closed container for about 30 minutes. To guarantee its effectiveness against Giardia, allow it to sit for at least 45 minutes.

Chlorine Dioxide-Based Tablets

This is probably the most powerful purification tablet currently available and is used to kill a wider range of pathogens including bacteria, viruses, and parasites such as cryptosporidium and giardia lambria. These tablets have fewer side effects than iodine and chlorine tablets and do not alter the taste of the water once purification is complete.

Chlorine dioxide tablets are especially effective against Giardia and Cryptosporidium as compared to iodine and chlorine tablets, however, for effective purification, water requires at least 4 hours to fully purify.

This chemical works via oxidation. The chemical infiltrates the microorganisms cell membrane and destroys the cytoplasm of the microorganism by responding with powerful amino acids. While the protective shells of Cryptosporidium and Giardia are somewhat resistant to iodine and chlorine, they are less protective against chlorine dioxide.

Chlorine dioxide tablets are only activated when contacted with water or moisture. If kept in a dry, airtight container, they can be stored for 4 years from the manufacturing date.

Types of tactical wallets

Tactical wallets come in a variety of sizes and designs. Some are meant for specific uses, like law enforcement or the military. Others are more versatile and can be used for multiple purposes. The size of the wallet is another consideration. Small tactical wallets are easier to conceal than larger ones. However, they're also harder to carry around because they don't hold as much cash or credit cards. Larger tactical wallets hold more cash or credit cards, making them easier to carry around. They're also easier to conceal when you keep them in your vehicle. If you plan on using a tactical wallet for multiple purposes, it's worth considering getting one that can accommodate more cash or credit cards. That way, you'll have options for all your needs.

Law enforcement

Law enforcement tactical wallets are designed specifically for law enforcement use. They're small enough to fit inside a pocket but large enough to hold cash or credit cards. These wallets are made with thick plastic so they don't break easily. The plastic is reinforced with aluminum to prevent rips or tears. The wallet itself is made from nylon fabric to prevent snags or abrasions. The wallet includes a flap that can be folded over to conceal contents. This feature makes it easier to conceal when you keep the wallet in your vehicle. Law enforcement tactical wallets are usually black or gray to make them easier to spot if you're driving through a neighborhood at night. The design is meant to be unobtrusive so you can focus on what matters most. The wallet includes a pocket for holding cash or credit cards, which makes it easier to pay for things. It's important to note that these wallets aren't waterproof. If you plan on keeping them in your vehicle, it's worth considering getting a waterproof tactical wallet. Otherwise, you'll need to pay extra for a water-resistant option.

Bifold pocket

Tactical minimalist wallet

Superbly functional take on run-of-the-mill EDC wallets. It takes the standard design of two steel plates wedged together and spices it up with an arsenal of downsized tools, including a pry tool, bolt wrenches, and the almighty bottle opener.

Tactical bifold wallet

Perfect solution for those into added functionality yet think the metal wallets are still not quite for them. It sheds hardened frames and casings for a nylon material.

Tactical wallet

Money clip

Types of military socks

Military and public service jobs are often very tough on your feet. Without proper footwear, painful blisters on toes and heels can be outright debilitating. While choosing the right military boots usually gets the most attention, sock selection is equally as important. Blisters are caused by friction and heat on the skin, so the socks you choose will be your first line of defense.

Combat Boot Socks

The Combat Boot Socks are made to be suitable for any kind of terrain and climate. One common characteristic is that these socks would extend over the calf, which is meant to give extra protection.

Desert Boot Socks

The Desert Boot Socks are tailored for hot weather conditions. It's one of the top picks if you are going to the desert.

Military Boot Socks

The abbreviation for Military Boot Socks is widely known as MB. It usually has mid-calf length.

Anti-Fatigue Boot Socks

Typically, anti-fatigue boot socks will be over-the-calf socks so that they can offer extra leg support.

If you are constantly involved in long hours of field operation, the anti-fatigue socks will come in handy. They are capable of giving your feet the support you need for you to be able to stay on your feet for long hours.

Physical Training Socks

Types of camping coffee makers

There are a lot of choices when it comes to camping coffee makers, and the trick is to make sure what you want fits the type of camping you plan on doing.

While there are numerous types of coffee makers, there are four broad categories: those that brew via pressure, those that allow the grounds to steep, those that brew via drip, and, finally, those that brew by boiling.

Pressure brew

This kind of coffee maker extracts the coffee goodness by forcing boiling/hot water through it via high pressure. To make a full cup of coffee, you typically have to add additional water after it's brewed. These are less common and tend to be a little more expensive for camping simply because of the need for perfect seals and high-pressure mechanisms.

Steep brew

A steep brew is one of the most simple, yet effective, methods of brewing up your coffee. All you need is a pot to add your hot water to the grounds; let it steep for three to five minutes, depending on taste; and then use something to push out the grounds and leave behind just the coffee.

There are other steep brew coffee makers out there, including coffee in tea bags, and the siphon-style that does a cool little magic trick by heating the water in a lower vessel, which is connected to a higher vessel via a tube of some kind. When the water gets to the boiling point, pressure forces the water into the upper chamber where the coffee grounds are. You then remove the heat source, and as the coffee cools, it slowly trickles down through a special filter back into the lower chamber. It's not too complicated, but awkward enough that you probably don't want to take it camping.

Drip brew

Dependable coffee makers and the trusty percolator coffee maker, fall into the drip brew category. This is a fundamentally simple type of coffee maker and is capable of making a lot of coffee at once. Water is boiled, then rises (in the case of a percolator) into where the grounds are stored, where it continues to boil until the heat is removed and the coffee drains through a filter to leave behind the grinds (and some oils if you're using a paper filter).

This simplicity of design makes percolators great coffee makers for camping, although the larger ones are likely too bulky and heavy for backpacking into more remote areas.

Boiling brew

This is the most basic way to make coffee, and the most common example is often called "cowboy coffee". While there are some ways of making the most of this, you're just boiling water with coffee grounds in it. After a few minutes, the grounds will be floating on a layer at the top, so sprinkle some cold water on top to make it sink. Then just pour carefully for a stout, slightly crunch cup of joe.

Types of life jackets

Life jackets come in many different sizes and designs. The most important thing to consider is how you plan on using the life jacket. If you're a recreational boater, you can get away with a small, basic one. But if you plan on taking your boat out into rough waters or fishing off-shore, you'll need something more substantial.

There are different life jackets for different boating activities. Below is a brief description of each type of life jacket, their intended use, and the buoyancy they provide.

Type I - Inherently buoyant

Recommended uses and features:

  • Intended Use: When cruising, racing, and fishing offshore, or when boating alone, or in stormy conditions.
  • Minimum Buoyancy:22 lbs. for adults. (11 lbs. for child size)
  • Additional Information: Best for open, rough, or remote water where rescue may be slow to arrive. Will turn MOST unconscious wearers face-up in water.

Offers the best protection, but is somewhat bulky and uncomfortable. Does the best job of retaining body heat, as it has additional foam and fabric, and keeps your head higher above water.

Currently, there aren't any Coast Guard-approved Type I inflatable PFDs available to the general public.

Type II - Inherently buoyant

Recommended uses and features:

  • Intended Use: Inland day cruising, fishing, and sailing. Good for boating in the light craft.
  • Minimum Buoyancy:15.5 lbs. for adult size.
  • Additional Information: Good for protected, inland water near shore, where chances of immediate rescue are good. Not suitable for extended survival in rough water. Will turn SOME unconscious wearers face-up in water. Poor performer in rough water often requires you to tread water to keep your head above water.

More comfortable but less buoyant than Type I. Provides far less flotation than a Type I.

Type II - Inflatable

Recommended uses and features:

  • Intended Use: For serious inland and near-shore cruising.
  • Minimum Buoyancy:34 lbs. for adult size.
  • Additional Information: Not guaranteed to turn unconscious wearer face-up.
  • Advantages: very comfortable, more buoyant than Type II Inherently Buoyant jackets.
  • Disadvantages: High price; may be manual or automatic.

There are many Type V (special use) inflatable jackets that provide Type II performance characteristics.

Inflatable PFDs are not meant for children under the age of 16.

Type III - Inherently buoyant

Recommended uses and features:

  • Intended Use: Supervised activities, such as sailing regattas, dinghy races, water skiing, fishing, canoeing, kayaking, and during personal watercraft operation.
  • Minimum Buoyancy: 15.5 lbs. for adult size.
  • Additional Information: Good for protected, inland water near shore, where the chance of immediate rescue is good. Not suitable for extended survival in rough water. Not designed to turn unconscious people face up in the water.

More comfortable to wear than a Type I or a Type II, but provides far less floatation than a Type I.

Type III - Inflatable

Recommended uses and features:

  • Intended Use: For boating inshore and near shore and for supervised activities such as sailing regattas, dinghy races, and canoeing.
  • Minimum Buoyancy:22.5 lbs. for adult size.
  • Additional Information: Not guaranteed to turn unconscious wearer face-up.
  • Advantages: more comfortable than a Type III Inherently Buoyant jacket.
  • Disadvantages: one manual inflation mechanism only.

Inflatable PFDs are not meant for children under the age of 16.

Type IV - Throwable Device

  • Intended Use: Type IV is designed to be thrown to an overboard victim or to supplement the buoyancy of a person overboard. It is not to be worn. Minimum buoyancy: 16.5 lbs. for ring buoy or 18 lbs. for boat cushion.
  • Additional Information: A Type IV throwable device can be a square style, a ring buoy, or a horseshoe buoy mounted on deck.

A Type IV is not for unconscious persons, non-swimmers, or children. Although these devices are often referred to as seat cushions, you should never use them as such. This degrades the foam and reduces the amount of floatation that is provided.

Note: Type IV devices must be IMMEDIATELY AVAILABLE for use. You must have one at arm's length to throw over the side in an emergency. Having one in a locker under the driver's seat isn't considered ""immediately available.""

Type V - Special use life jackets

  • Intended Use: Restricted to the special use for which each is designed, for example, sailboard harness, deck suit, paddling vest, commercial white water vest, or float coats.
  • Minimum Buoyancy:15.5 to 22 lbs. for adult size.
  • Additional Information: Must be worn when underway to meet minimum US Coast Guard requirements. Simply having a Type V PFD on board will not meet the USCG carriage requirements.

Type V - Automatic inflation models

  • Intended Use: Restricted to the one use for which it is designed, ex. belt pack, deck suit, float coat.
  • Minimum Buoyancy: 22.5 to 34 lbs. depending on style.
  • Additional Information: Must be worn to meet federal requirements.

Not guaranteed to turn an unconscious wearer face-up. Some manufacturers claim Type II performance. Some models feature a combination of CO2 inflation and built-in foam and provide 15.5 to 22 lbs. of buoyancy.

Type V - Hybrid Inflation

Some special notes:

  • Intended Use: Models recommended for boating activities where rescue is nearby and must be worn when underway.
  • Minimum Buoyancy: Have 7.5 lbs. of built-in foam buoyancy and can be inflated to 22 lbs.
  • Additional Information: More comfortable to wear than Type I or Type II, but are inadequate for unconscious overboard victims.
  • Inflation Mechanism: When activated, a CO2 cartridge is pierced, releasing gas to inflate the device. Water-activated models inflate automatically when submerged in water.

Manual units are activated by yanking a pull tab. Both types of inflatables feature blow-tubes to provide a backup method of inflation. It is important to follow the manufacturer's instructions for checking and maintaining your inflation mechanism.

Types of survival backpacks

Survival backpacks are designed for emergency preparedness. They need to be lightweight, durable, and compact enough to fit inside a vehicle or backpack. A true survival backpack includes plenty of features found on other packs, but their quality matters more than most. Additionally, how a specific collection of features comes together can determine a pack's suitability for emergency survival.

That said, survival packs, like bug-out bags, can be classified according to their intended emergency setting: urban, wilderness, and tactical.

Urban

As the name implies, urban survival packs look right at home in a metropolitan or suburban setting with repurposed school and EDC bags filling the role well.

Wilderness

wilderness backpacks tend to be tougher, lighter, and more technical in their design and features; hiking and hunting backpacks fill this role most often.

Tactical

Tactical or military survival packs are heavier-duty and heavier than wild survival bags and have lots of PALS webbing to accommodate extra gear.

Types of survival kits

Survival kits are designed for different purposes. Some are meant to be used as a standalone item, while others are intended to be part of a larger kit. The key is knowing which type you need and finding the right one. Here's a breakdown of the most common options.

Emergency kits

These kits are meant to be kept in your home or car at all times. They usually include basic supplies like flashlights, batteries, and water filters. Emergency kits are great for people who live in an area prone to natural disasters like hurricanes or earthquakes. They're also good for people who plan on being away from home for long periods, like those who travel frequently. Emergency kits are inexpensive because they're made with generic products. You can find them for under $10 online. That said, they're not ideal for people who plan on using them regularly. If you only plan on using the contents once every few years, then this is a great option. Otherwise, you'll have to pay more for what you want.

Mini survival kits

Mini survival kits or "Altoids" tin survival kits are small kits that contain a few basic survival tools. These kits often include a small compass, waterproof matches, minimum fishing tackle, a large plastic bag, a small candle, a jigsaw blade, a craft knife or scalpel blade, and/or a safety pin/s.

Emergency kit

The most common and the most used one is the emergency kit. Emergency kits are easily available as well and are used to aid a person in surviving for 72 hours during any rescue situation or in escaping from any natural disaster or any emergency including earthquakes, hurricanes, tsunamis, floods, and so on. An emergency kit is also known as a disaster bag or quick run bag which is a small portable kit containing all the survival supplies essential for the survival of a person in the above-stated condition. It focuses on safely evacuating the person (surviving for 72 hours) instead of focusing on the person's long-term survival. The social movement by the individuals or group of individuals, where they specifically keep themselves prepared for natural disasters and emergencies such as those mentioned above and their effect on the political and economic structure of the society, is commonly known as survivalism. These emergency kits (also called personal emergency relocation kits) are quite commonly used in this subculture. If a disaster occurs, its main purpose is to evacuate the survivor as soon as possible. Therefore, it is quite helpful and necessary to carry this kit with you when you are traveling or staying in another place.

Lifeboat survival kits

The first one on the list is the lifeboat survival kit which is perfectly stowed in life rafts. These life rafts or lifeboats are rigid and firm. The lifeboat survival kits aim at providing the basic human survival supplies and tools which help passengers in surviving until they reach a rescue place or are rescued by someone. One lifeboat survival kit can be used by six people at one time since it includes more quantities of survival tools and supplies.

Lifeboat survival kits are stowed in inflatable or rigid lifeboats or life rafts. These kits provide basic survival tools and supplies to enable passengers to survive until they are rescued.

Sporting survival kits

These kits are geared toward sportsmen or outdoor enthusiasts. They often include items like fishing tackle, hunting gear, camping equipment, and survival knives. Sporting survival kits are great for people who plan on spending time outdoors, but they're not ideal for people who don't plan. These kits tend to be expensive because they're made with high-quality materials. It's worth it if you plan on using the contents, but you'll have to pay up to get what you want.

Types of shooting gloves

Shooting gloves are designed for specific purposes. Some are meant to protect against water damage, while others are specifically made for use in cold-weather environments. Shooting gloves can be found in a variety of different materials, including cotton and wool, but the most popular option is leather. Leather is durable and easy to clean, making it a great choice for shooting gloves. It's also hypoallergenic, so if you have allergies, this is a good option. However, leather does scratch easily, so it isn't recommended for use with sharp objects. If you want to stick with leather, make sure to buy gloves that are not scratched or worn down. This will extend their lifespan.

Shooting gloves are categorized into three different types. There are lightweight, which are often specialized gloves; middleweight, which is well rounded; and heavyweight, which are meant for hard, specialized use. Each category has its distinct differences and uses.

Lightweight

These gloves are light. Though they are generally affordable, they are not necessarily cheaply made. Usually, these trade insulation and sometimes durability for dexterity, feel, and grip.

Consider these a specialty glove. A professional glove. Sleek and specialized. These gloves can sometimes hack it in the field but are not purpose-built to withstand harsh conditions.

Middleweight

Middleweight is usually where well-rounded gloves can be found. Unless you require carbon-fiber knuckle protection or extreme insulation, this is probably about as high in protection as you need to go. Your hands are well-protected against minor scrapes and bumps at this level, but do not go grabbing suppressors or expect to punch through the drywall. In this weight class, you might get some weather protection and insulation, but not enough for the arctic.

Heavyweight

These, like the lightweights, are specialized. They just exist on the other end of the spectrum and can be specialized in any number of ways. The tradeoff here is usually in the dexterity and feel categories.

These are for hard use and will protect your hands, whether from physical dangers or the elements. In this category, there's a wide range of gloves for a wide range of applications. While these may not be the best shooting gloves for flat range, these are usually the best shooting gloves for situations they were designed for.

Types of water bottles

Water bottles are containers used to hold water, liquids, or other beverages for consumption. A water bottle lets an individual drink and transports a beverage from one place to another. A water bottle is usually made of plastic, metal, or glass. Water bottles come in different shapes, colors, and sizes. They can be either disposable or reusable.

Here are some of the most common types of water bottles, divided by material and other features.

Single-Use Plastic

Single-use, pre-filled plastic water bottles. In some countries with low-quality tap water, citizens also use bottled water for health reasons. The increase in the use of single-use personal plastic water bottles has contributed to the litter problem, so reusable plastic bottles are better for the planet.

Reusable Plastic

Plastic is perhaps the most popular material used for water bottles. It is lightweight, making plastic water bottles easily transportable. The biggest concern about plastic is its environmental impact. It is disposable, which means most people throw it away after its first use. However, there are more rigid types of plastics that can be reused. BPA, an endocrine-disrupting substance, is a biohazard in plastic bottles. BPA-free plastic should be chosen, especially for water bottles for kids. Multi-use water bottles can be made from polypropylene, high-density polyethylene (HDPE), low-density polyethylene (LDPE), or copolyester.

Glass

Glass is considered the healthiest choice of material for water bottles. It is a non-permeable and natural raw material. It is known for its purity so that it won't give water a weird taste or odor. It can also be recycled infinitely, making it better for the environment than hard-to-recycle materials. However, the biggest problem with glass is that it is fragile and must be handled with care as it can easily break. It is also heavy, which compromises its portability.

Aluminum

Aluminum water bottles are lighter than glass or stainless steel, making them ideal for those concerned about portability. One of the problems with aluminum is that it can leach into the liquid. There must be a liner on the bottle to have no direct contact between water and aluminum. The liner is typically made of resin. The resin liner must be BPA-free.

Copper

Copper is one of the trendiest water bottle materials. It is shiny and sleek, making it a popular choice for a stylish container. However, while copper water bottles may look great, water with a high level of copper can cause side effects such as diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting. A proper liner between the copper and water must be used.

Stainless Steel

Stainless steel is another good option for the types of water bottles. It is heavy but shatter-resistant, unlike the more fragile glass. Stainless steel is also a food-grade material, meaning it doesn't add any flavor to water.

Collapsible

This water bottle is ideal for easy travel. When the bottle is empty, it can be folded, which makes it space-efficient. When choosing collapsible water bottles, they should be strong enough to withstand wear, mainly because of the folding.

Filtered

Filtered bottles are designed for outdoor adventures such as hiking and camping. They allow people to drink water from different sources. The built-in filtration system helps eliminate the contaminants present in the water to ensure it will be safe. The type of filter that it uses is an essential consideration. Carbon and ultraviolet filters are the most popular materials used.

Insulated

To keep water, or whatever liquid a bottle may contain, hot or cold for an extended period, insulated water bottles are needed. They are made of a unique material to keep the temperature of the water for hours.

Bamboo

An eco-friendly option for water bottles is bamboo. It is an organic and renewable material, making it user and planet-friendly. Today, bamboo is commonly used for commemorative water bottles, such as weddings and corporate giveaways, or customized with engraved names.

Smart

Water bottles equipped with smart functions are a newer technology. Smart water bottles have digital systems that can connect to smartphones or laptops. They have alarms and reminders that can give notifications when it's time to drink more water. These bottles make it easier to stay hydrated throughout the day. Aside from drinking reminders, some smart water bottles can also be connected to a compatible mobile application for more functions.

Types of camping tables

There is no doubt that camping is becoming a more popular global trend. As the popularity of camping grows, many manufacturers concentrate on producing camping equipment and furniture. A camping table is one of the most important pieces of camping equipment. This guide will undoubtedly assist you if you are looking for a camping table and are unsure which type to select.

Side Table

Side tables are smaller than all other camping tables. These are specially designed to support and bear small items. Side tables may not be a good option for eating. However, they help support many other things, including drinks, lighting, bags, and smaller items. Unlike folding or other durable tables, side tables aren't the option for sitting and putting extra weight on them. Typically, the camping side table is folded compactly, working as a television dinner table. As they are waterproof or sturdy, camping side tables have high tensile strength.

Folding Camping Table

A folding table is perhaps the most common type of camping table in today's market. A folding camping table shrinks to a compact and flat shape. You can easily bend the legs of a folding table inwards and tuck them behind the surface. Most folding camping tables are designed with aluminum and other quality material. So, they can support a lot of weight during camping. A folding camping table can rise relatively high off the floor, depending on the structure. However, placing a folding camping table on a flat surface is advisable to help prevent tipping.

Roll-up Table

A roll-up camping table can help you in a variety of ways. For example, they help you hold or support drinks, utensils, bags, dishes, etc. They can bear weight from 50 lbs to 100 lbs. however, some are too small and can only bear up to 40 lbs. Depending on your conditions, you can choose the supporting level of the roll-up camping table. They are different in size and are made up of different materials.

Tall Table

If you are going camping with your family member, colleagues, and university friends, you need to have a pretty big table for camping. The big size camping table helps you organize more items on your table and provides more areas to socialize with each other during camping resting time. So, you need to know how many people will be the members or parts of your camping expedition. The number of campers will decide the size of the table.

Low Table

A low camping table is also a common type used by campers. Low tables have numerous benefits. For example, they allow campers to sit on the ground floor and easily access the table. In addition, they are not so high from the ground. If you use a low table, there is no need to carry chairs and sofas. You need to have a sitting mat or carpet. Place it on the ground to easily access the table and enjoy your camping time.

Types of dry bags

The type of dry bag you require is determined by the purpose for which you intend to use it. If you need to protect your phones or cameras, a small waterproof pouch may be what you need.

A lightweight dry bag may be required for clothing and other medium-sized items. More information about the various types of dry bags that can be used for various purposes can be found below:

Waterproof pouch

Waterproof pouch is usually a see-through waterproof bag that is small enough to fit small items such as phones, gadgets, and small paper documents. It has a roll-top opening to make sure it is properly sealed.

Lightweight dry bag

Lightweight dry bag has the capacity from 1 liter up to 80 liters. Clothes, food, and/or electronics can be stored in this kind of dry bag. In addition, wet items can be separated from dry items using this bag.

PVC dry bag

If you need an ultimate strong dry bag, PVC dry bag is a good choice. It is made from PVC with welded seams and is quite heavy compared to the other types because of its toughness and density. It is usually used in extreme sports as it can withstand pressure and other force.

Heavyweight dry bag

Heavyweight dry bag can contain larger items or more medium-sized items. It has a capacity that ranges from 16 liters to 45 liters.

Holdalls and rucksacks

These kinds of dry bags are as tough as PVC dry bags with welded seams. They have a capacity from 35 to 70 liters.

Types of chronograph watches

There are three main types of chronograph watches, and each has its place. The first is the basic watch with a chronograph function. They're easy to use and accurate enough for most people. However, they don't offer much in terms of features or design. If you want more from your watch, you'll need to move up to one of the other two options.

Basic Chronograph Watch

The basic chronograph watch is the simplest option. It's just a watch with a chronograph face on it. You can get these for as low as $50, so they're a great option for beginners. They're easy to use and accurate enough for most people. However, they don't offer many features or design options. If you want more from your watch, you'll need to move up to one of the other options.

Digital Chronograph Watch

The digital chronograph watch is the next step up from the basic watch. These are more expensive options that cost upwards of $300, but they're worth it if you have the money to spend. They're easy to use and accurate enough for most people. They offer features like date display and 24-hour time format, which is nice to have. They also offer a variety of different watch faces to choose from. If you want more from your watch, you'll need to move up to one of the other options.

Analog Chronograph Watch

The analog chronograph watch is the most advanced option. It's the most expensive option, but it's worth it if you have the money to spend.

Types of body armor

Body armor comes in a variety of different categories, and it's important to know which one you need before you buy. Body armor is designed for specific purposes, so it's important to pick the right kind for your needs.

Body Armor Vest

Also known as a bulletproof or ballistic vest, this is an item of body armor that helps absorb and reduce the impact on the torso from fragmentation from explosions and firearm-fired projectiles. This is usually worn by police officers, correctional officers, security guards, and some regular citizens. Depending on what you need protection from, there are different types of vests, for different levels of protection.

Soft Armor Plates

Soft armor plates are flexible and soft, but still extremely strong and protective. They are light and not bulky and are usually worn as a concealed body armor vest or plate carrier.

Hard Armor Plates

Hard body armor plates provide the highest level of protection possible but are not as comfortable or light as soft armor plates. They can be inserted into plate carriers or body armor vests.

Concealed Vest

Concealed body armor vests are designed to be worn under street clothes, or uniforms. Due to soft armor panels, they are designed not to be seen, but to provide full protection from bullet and stab threats. They protect the front, back, and sides of the torso.

Full Body Tactical Armor

The military usually wears full body armor. It consists of front, side, and back protection in a vest, which can be joined with armor that covers the majority of the body such as a helmet and protection for the arms and legs. This is intended to be worn on show above clothes, as opposed to the concealed vest.

Bulletproof Military Plate Carrier

Plate carriers are another type of bulletproof vest, but which are lighter and more comfortable than full-body armor vests. They can hold soft or hard armor plates to provide different levels of protection required. As they are lighter options yet still provide very strong protection, they are a popular choice for military and police services.

Edge-Blade and Spike Protection

Edge-blade refers to commercial knives that do not come to a fine point. Protection against this blade is against slashing or stabbing of such an instrument. Spike weapons refer to any harmful instrument that has a fine-pointed tip. This does not include shrapnel that is projected from an explosive. Spike weapons could refer to a syringe or anything that has a sharp-tipped edge.

Protection against stabbings may be slightly different from ballistic protection. The stab vest may have fibers woven tighter and more layers to prevent an edge-blade or spike from penetrating the skin.

Multi Armor Threat

Multi-threat armor protects against multiple different types of weapons and attacks. This type of armor is useful if someone is facing multiple threats or does not know what weapons their attackers may have. This type of armor is beneficial for people working in Law Enforcement, who are required to have complete protection against a wide variety of threats. The types of body armor could be to have stab-proof vests, which are also spike-proof at the same time.

Types of camping knives

Camping knives come in many different forms and sizes. No matter what task you have in mind or what your local restrictions are, it's probable that you'll easily find a camping knife that suits your needs.

Fixed blade

A fixed blade is any knife with a blade that is fixed in place, meaning that it doesn't have a pivot, and is firmly, immovably attached to the handle. They're essentially the opposite of pocket knives. The blade is always exposed unless it's covered by a sheath. They're simple, easier to manufacture than folding knives, and very user-friendly due to the absence of a confusing locking mechanism.

Fixed blade camping knives come in many varieties, including drop-point and clip-point knives. The better-designed fixed blades are also full-tang, where the part of the blade that's part of the handle is the same size and shape as the handle, as this provides the greatest overall strength. The majority of cheap camping fixed blades, unfortunately, are not; these knives have a thin metal tail that is typically pinned or glued inside of the handle and are more prone to breaking.

Folding

Also referred to as a pocket knife, a folder is a compact knife that features one or more blades that fold up into the handle, instead of using a bulky sheath. Meant to fit easily inside your pocket, these knives are legal to carry in most places, and are convenient to carry and use daily. They are frequently smaller than fixed blades, with blades typically between three and four inches long, although many exceptions are both longer and shorter than this. While these aren't common choices for camping knives, they can be quite handy for anything from peeling an apple to cutting rope. Though these folding knives are typically smaller and not as strong as their fixed blade siblings, they're highly versatile.

Multitool

While technically a variant of a folding knife, the main selling point of a multitool isn't the blade itself, but rather the multiple tools that accompany it. This can include anything from pliers or scissors to screwdrivers and corkscrews.

Types of gas masks

even though gas masks are a subtype of respirator, words and their definitions change. The full-face respirator is commonly known and referred to as a gas mask by laymen, preppers, and survivalists, whereas a respirator is a filter that only covers the nose and mouth and offers partial face protection.

Gas Mask

  • Protection: Full-face, or full head protection.
  • Filter: All hazardous materials depending on the type of filter installed.
  • Size and weight: Bulkier, some types have additional components like a separate air supply. Can be heavy due to additional components, filters, and a portable air supply.
  • Cost: Expensive.

Elastomeric Full-Facepiece Respirator (Gas Mask)

This is similar to the half-facepiece respirator but covers the whole face. It protects against particles, gases, and vapors depending on the type of cartridge or filter installed. There are different makes and models out in the market. This is what preppers generally refer to as a gas mask.

Powered Air Purifying Respirators (PAPRs)

This type of respirator covers the whole head up to the shoulders. It has a battery-powered blower that pulls air through an attached filter, canister, or cartridges. It protects against particles, gases, and vapors when equipped with the appropriate filters. It is loose fitting and can be used with facial hair.

Supplied Air Respirators (SAR)

SAR are full face masks that are connected to a hose that supplies clean compressed air from a separate source. The mask has a one-way valve to release exhaled air. This equipment is lightweight and is used while working for extended periods in environments that are not immediately dangerous to life and health (IDLH).

Self-Contained Breathing Apparatus (SCBA)

SCBA is used for entry into or escapes from the IDLH environment. It comes with a portable oxygen supply, and can either be an open-circuit (OC-SCBA), or a closed-circuit system (CC-SCBA).

OC-SCBA provides air via a high-pressure tank and the exhaust exhaled air into the atmosphere. CC-SCBA on the other hand recirculates the exhaled air after the CO2 was filtered out, leaving only the oxygen. This rebreathing mechanism extends its operational time.

The Self-Contained Underwater Breathing Apparatus or SCUBA is a form of SCBA. However, the regular SCBA is not rated for underwater use.

Combination Respirators

There are 2 types of combinations used: Supplied Air Respirator + SCBA, and Supplied Air Respirator + PAPRs. The SAR + SCBA has a self-contained air supply if the primary air supply fails. It can be used in an IDLH environment. The SAR + PAPR on the other hand cannot be used in an IDLH due to its non-existent backup air supply.

Types of hiking daypacks

There are the types of hiking daypacks that you need to know before making a purchase.

General Daypacks

General daypacks, which are the most popular daypack, work well for most of life's mundane tasks. They are fairly inexpensive, ideal for campus life, and work well for bike commuting and general travel. In short, they are excellent bags for "around town" and "around the city" use. The multitude of pockets allows for excellent organization, and the large capacities make it easy to bring everything but the kitchen sink when the need arises.

Technical Daypacks

Recognizing general daypacks weren't ideal for serious day hiking trips, manufacturers created smaller capacity packs with the same features found in full-size backpacks. While these smaller ability packs are still called "daypacks", these packs are also known as "technical daypacks", since they share the common technical features found in larger backpacks.

Types of survival lighters

Survival lighters come in all different sizes, shapes, and prices. There's a good chance you can find one that fits your budget, but it's important to know what you're getting into before you pull the trigger.

Traditional survival lighters

These are the most common type of survival lighters on the market today. They are made from metal or aluminum, have a long-lasting flame, and weigh less than an apple. The downside is that they aren't very efficient at burning fuel, so you'll need to refill more often. Also, they don't last as long as other options because they are made from cheap metals. If you want something reliable for survival use, this is the way to go.

Gas-fueled survival lighters

This is another option worth considering. Gas-fueled survival lighters are popular because they burn fuel quickly and last longer than traditional options. However, they are also more expensive. Gas is expensive, so you'll need to plan when you buy one. Also, they are heavier than traditional options, so you'll need to make sure you can comfortably carry them around. Gas-fueled survival lighters are great for camping trips or emergency kits, but they aren't ideal for survival use. Gas is flammable, so you'll need to be careful with these lighters.

Types of rolling backpacks

Rolling backpacks are designed for specific uses. Some are meant to carry a sleeping bag, tent, or other camping gear. Others are built for hiking packs or skis. Still, others are built for motorcycles. The list goes on and on. There's a reason for each design choice. Rolling backpacks are made from durable materials that can withstand wear and tear. They're also compact enough to fit in the bottom of a pack without adding weight. These features make them ideal for carrying camping equipment or skiing supplies. However, they aren't built to withstand harsh weather conditions like rain or snow. If you plan to use your rolling backpack in cold climates, it's best to buy one with an additional pocket or strap for extra protection against water damage.

Sleeping backpacks

These are the most popular rolling backpacks because they're specifically designed for camping trips. Sleeping backpacks are larger than typical rolling backpacks so they can accommodate more gear. Sleeping backpacks have two straps so you can secure them to your pack frame. This allows you to roll them up without worrying about damaging them. Sleeping backpacks are usually made from ripstop nylon so they can withstand wear and tear. The downside is that these bags don't offer much protection against water damage. If you plan to use your sleeping backpack in cold climates, it's best to buy one with an additional pocket or strap for extra protection against water damage.

Hiking backpacks
